title: Womenâ€™s Cycling Weekly: Issue 25
content:
Hello! Welcome to Womenâ€™s Cycling Weekly issue 25ğŸš´â€â™€ï¸

Watching the Giro this week got me thinking about how brilliant it would be to have a womenâ€™s race on this scale. Wall-to-wall daily coverage (unless it rains) and extensive insights and analysis into the minutiae of the racing (just HOW many podcasts are there?!) all played out in front of stunning scenery â€” having so much excess coverage that you can afford to cut away to castles and other monuments is male privilege.Â 

Part of the background celebrations for the race included the 700th anniversary of Danteâ€™s death and so the parallels between grand tour racing and his epic poetry were duly drawn. The closest the womenâ€™s peloton has to a grand tour â€” the Giro Rosa â€” isnâ€™t even broadcast and so the daily vignettes of divine comedy go largely unseen. The disconnect that this causes fuels the narrative that nobody is interested in womenâ€™s racing because, without an audience, the protagonists are invisible and so too is the drama (if a tree falls in the woods etc.).Â 

Which brings me onto theÂ news from this weekÂ about the impending 2022 womenâ€™s Tour de France which caused plenty of excitement. If the race does justice to the world-class riders who turn up on the startline then it will be a huge turning point, but Iâ€™ll leave the unbridled optimism to everyone else and reserve the right to uphold my cynicism when it comes to ASO right up until Iâ€™m stood watching theÂ grand depart. Also, a moment of pause for the fact that we will never see Anna van der Breggen race a womenâ€™s Tour de France ğŸ’”.Â 

Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™m not alone in thinking just how great it would be to sit down and immerse myself in three (ish) weeks worth of womenâ€™s racing as we do with menâ€™s GTs. How I would love to be scrabbling to keep up with the myriad narratives woven throughout the race as riders take their own journeys throughÂ Inferno,Â Purgatorio, and (for the scant few)Â ParadisoÂ (is it obvious that Iâ€™ve never studied Dante?)Â 

To watch and enjoy racing without feeling constantly prickled by some sense of injustice is a rare privilege in womenâ€™s racing, but one which I think we all hope might become the norm in the future. Just leave out 200km snore-fest stages, yeah?

NewsÂ ğŸ“°

  • Yes, Christian Prudhomme has said that aÂ womenâ€™s Tour de Franceâ€œwill take place next year, thatâ€™s certain.â€Â He also came out with such charming details as â€œToday, all the womenâ€™s races that we organise lose us money,â€ and, â€œIf it makes money, thatâ€™s great, but it mustnâ€™t lose money or it will end up like the Tour in the 80s and it will die.â€ ğŸ‘
  • Elsewhere, Olympic team selections are being made forÂ TokyoÂ with theÂ NetherlandsÂ andÂ FranceÂ among the first to announce their squads.Â Anna van der Breggen,Â Demi Vollering,Â Annemiek van Vleuten, andÂ Marianne VosÂ will make up the Dutch squad while a lonelyÂ Juliette LabousÂ will race for France, with national champion andÂ Trek-SegafredoÂ workhorseÂ Audrey Cordon-RagotÂ snubbed.Â 
  • A report byÂ The TimesÂ this week revealed that Britainâ€™s most successful Paralympian, cyclistÂ Dame Sarah Storey, returned an adverse analytical finding for salbutamol after the 2012 Paralympic Games although she was later given a backdated Therapeutic Use Exemption by the British Paralympic AssociationÂ which was approved by International Paralympic Committee. A spokesman for the BPA said: â€œWe are entirely confident that the correct procedures were followed at the time and have all the relevant supporting documentation.â€Â

Results ğŸ†

  • Results from stages one and two at theÂ Setmana Ciclista Valenciana 2.1Â were covered in last weekâ€™s issue but the following dayÂ Alice BarnesÂ took her first win in almost two years forÂ Canyon//SRAMÂ on stage three while Slovenian time trial championÂ Urska ZigartÂ ofÂ Team BikeExchangeÂ went solo to take the final stage.Â Annemiek van VleutenÂ snapped up the GC by a solid 2:16 ahead ofÂ Mavi Garcia(Ale BTC Ljubljana) with van Vleutenâ€™sÂ MovistarÂ teammateÂ Katrine AalerudÂ a further 14 seconds back in third.Â 
  • Meanwhile, in Belgium, it was aÂ Team DSMÂ 1-2 and an all-U23 podium atÂ GP Eco-Struct 1.2Â withÂ Lorena WiebesÂ sprinting to the win ahead of teammateÂ Susanne AndersenÂ withÂ Amber van der HulstÂ ofÂ Parkhotel ValkenburgÂ in third.Â 
  • U23 World ChampionÂ Loana LecomteÂ ofÂ MassiÂ took an emphatic win at theÂ MTB XCO UCI World Cup race in Albstadt, Germany.Â World ChampionÂ Pauline Ferrand PrevotÂ ofÂ Absoluteâ€“Absalonâ€“BMCcame second with 22-year-oldÂ Haley BattenÂ ofÂ Trinity RacingÂ taking third in her first elite World Cup race. Watch highlightsÂ here.
  • Plenty of soggy bottoms at the first of the twoÂ Navarra 1.1Â races yesterday, the final 60km of which *live broadcast klaxon* were on Eurosport and GCN+.Â Annemiek van VleutenÂ took the win for the second year in a row, this time in a home race for her newÂ MovistarÂ team. She looked to have it in the bag until a stormingÂ Demi VolleringÂ ofÂ SD WorxÂ got agonisingly close to catching her on the final descent into the finish and fell just short of pipping her compatriot in a protracted sprint.Â Elisa Longo BorghiniÂ ofÂ Trek-SegafredoÂ â€”Â who is coming back from a post-classics breakÂ â€” took third. Highlights on GCN+ and Eurosport.

Upcoming RacesÂ ğŸ“…

  • Day two inÂ NavarraÂ will be underway as you read this (youâ€™d better be watching from 5pm CET on Eurosport/GCN) the 124.8km course starts and finishes in Pamplona and is a lumpy affair. Can AVV do the double again? More details on the raceÂ website, and you can see a startlistÂ here.Â

  • Another 1.1 race in the north-west of Spain this weekend takes place on Sunday, theÂ Gran Premio Ciudad de Eibar.Â Unfortunately, it doesnâ€™t look like this one will be broadcast but expect many of the same big riders to take to theÂ startline.Â 
  • Same goes for theÂ 1.1 Durango â€“ Durango Emakumeen SariaÂ on Tuesday 18th just two days beforeâ€¦
  • The first Womenâ€™s WorldTour stage race of 2021!Â Vuelta a Burgos FeminasÂ takes place next week fromÂ Thursday 20th â€“ Sunday 23rd.Itâ€™s one for the climbers and if yesterday was anything to go by itâ€™s going to be a tooth-and-nail battle for that top GC spot. Race previewÂ here. (Sparse) startlistÂ here. Race websiteÂ here. Stages will be broadcast on GCN/Eurosport from 12:00 CET.

The latestÂ episode of Matt Stephens unpluggedÂ features a great chat with yesterdayâ€™s third-place and all-round likeable characterÂ Elisa Longo Borghini.Â 

Pain in the bum ğŸ‘

Saddle sores are an issue taking up a considerable chunk of my thoughts at the moment. My body (or rather my chamois/saddle) decided that a piece Iâ€™m working on about womenâ€™s saddles should become an immersive experience and I am suffering (for the very first time despite over 6 years of riding including racing) from a proper saddle sore. TMI? IDC. Because this is a real issue and the taboo that surrounds it is part of the problem.Â 

If I havenâ€™t already made it clear, my stance in this newsletter is that I am not an expert who has everything covered all of the time â€” in other words: Iâ€™ll probably get stuff wrong/miss things and thatâ€™s ok. On this particular matter, however, I was kicking myself that I found out about thisÂ very exciting piece of bib short innovationÂ through Caroline Criado Perezâ€™s (brilliant)Â Invisible Women newsletterÂ before I found out about it myself. But then I thought: hang on, why isnâ€™t the cycling world shouting about this from the rooftops? Oh yeah, because itâ€™s for women.Â 

Anyway, well bloody done toÂ EnduraÂ for being, not the first, but one of very few brands to actually develop products for female cyclists using actual real-life women instead of simply guessing what women might require. For further reading on the topic see:Â Hannah Dines for The Guardian, and if you havenâ€™t read the Rouleur womenâ€™s issue (why not?) then you can listen to a piece from it by the brilliant Orla Chennaoui on this issueÂ here.

Thatâ€™s all ğŸ‘‹

A slightly shorter edition this week but I hope you enjoyed it nevertheless!

Until next time,

Amy x
